When holiday lets pay business rates instead of council tax.

Holiday lets: council tax or business rates?

Holiday lets and self-catering accommodation occupy a unique position in the tax system. They can be liable for either council tax OR business rates, depending on how much they are let out.

The key difference is:

  • Business rates: If the property meets strict letting criteria (140/70 days)
  • Council tax with second homes premium: If the property does not meet the criteria (200% of standard charge from April 2025)

The 140/70 day criteria

To pay business rates instead of council tax, your holiday let must meet ALL of these criteria:

All 4 criteria must be met

1. Available for at least 140 days

The property must be available to let commercially for short periods totalling at least 140 days in:

  • The previous 12 months, AND
  • The current 12 months (or you intend to make it available)

Note: This is about availability, not actual bookings. The property must be genuinely advertised and available at market rates.

2. Actually let for at least 70 days

The property must be actually let commercially for at least 70 days in the previous 12 months.

Important: Your own use does not count. This must be paying guests on short-term lets at market rates.

3. Commercial basis

The property must be let on a commercial basis with a view to making a profit at market rates.

This means genuine commercial letting, not occasional use by friends and family at low rates.

4. Future intention

You must intend to make the property available for at least 140 days in the following 12 months.

This must be a genuine intention, evidenced by continued advertising and availability.

What counts as a 'short period'?

A short period means stays of less than 140 consecutive days by the same person or group.

If you let to the same person for 140 days or more, it may be treated as a long-term let and subject to council tax, not business rates.

Who decides: The Valuation Office Agency (VOA)

The Valuation Office Agency (VOA), not the council, decides whether a property pays council tax or business rates.

How the VOA makes decisions

The VOA will look at:

  • Your letting records (bookings, income)
  • Advertising and availability evidence
  • Your business plan and intentions
  • Whether the property is genuinely run as a commercial business
  • Market rates for similar properties in the area

Contact the VOA

If you think your holiday let should pay business rates, or if you disagree with a decision, contact the VOA:

Contact the Valuation Office Agency

Council tax vs business rates: what's the difference?

Business rates (if you meet the criteria)

  • Small business rate relief: Properties with a rateable value under ¬£12,000 may pay no business rates at all
  • Properties between ¬£12,000 and ¬£15,000: May get partial relief
  • No second homes premium
  • Treated as a business: Can claim business expenses for tax purposes

Council tax (if you don't meet the criteria)

  • Standard council tax charge PLUS 100% second homes premium from April 2025
  • This means 200% of the normal council tax (double)
  • Significantly more expensive than business rates for most properties
  • Cannot claim business rate relief

Example: A Band D property normally pays ¬£2,238.77 per year. With the second homes premium, it will pay ¬£4,477.54 per year from April 2025.

Small business rate relief for holiday lets

If your holiday let qualifies for business rates, you may also qualify for small business rate relief.

Eligibility for small business rate relief

  • Rateable value under ¬£12,000: 100% relief (pay nothing)
  • Rateable value between ¬£12,000 and ¬£15,000: Tapered relief (partial)
  • Rateable value over ¬£15,000: No relief, pay full business rates

Most small holiday cottages and flats have rateable values under ¬£12,000, meaning they could pay no business rates at all.

How to apply for small business rate relief

If your property is on the business rates list and has a rateable value under ¬£15,000, you can apply for small business rate relief.

Contact our Business Rates team:

  • Phone: 01452 396396
  • Email: revenues@gloucester.gov.uk

What happens if you don't meet the criteria?

If your holiday let does not meet the 140/70 day criteria, it will be liable for council tax, not business rates.

From 1 April 2025, this means you will pay:

  • The standard council tax for your property's band
  • PLUS a 100% second homes premium
  • Total: 200% of the standard council tax charge

Action required: If you're currently paying business rates but won't meet the 140/70 criteria, you need to contact the VOA to have your property reassessed. Otherwise you may be liable for backdated council tax.

Evidence to keep

To prove your holiday let meets the criteria, you should keep detailed records:

Availability evidence (140 days)

  • Calendar showing when the property was available to book
  • Screenshots of listings on Airbnb, Booking.com, etc.
  • Website availability calendar
  • Booking agent contracts and statements

Actual letting evidence (70 days)

  • Booking records with dates and guest names
  • Income records (bank statements, booking platform reports)
  • Guest feedback and reviews
  • Cleaning and changeover records

Commercial basis evidence

  • Pricing comparable to market rates
  • Business plan or marketing strategy
  • Advertising spend and marketing materials
  • Terms and conditions for bookings

Future intention evidence

  • Forward bookings
  • Continuing advertising and promotion
  • Investment in the property or marketing
  • Business planning documents

Keep these records for at least 3 years. The VOA may ask to see them at any time to verify your property still qualifies for business rates.

Common scenarios

Scenario 1: New holiday let business

Question: I've just converted my property to a holiday let. Can I pay business rates straight away?

Answer: For the first year, you need to show you intend to meet the 140/70 criteria. This means:

  • Have a business plan showing you expect to let for 70+ days
  • Actively advertise the property for at least 140 days
  • Set prices at market rates

In the second year, the VOA will check you actually achieved 70 days of letting. If you didn't, you may be moved back to council tax.

Scenario 2: Below 70 days actual letting

Question: My property was available for 140 days but only let for 50 days. What happens?

Answer: You don't meet the criteria. Your property will be liable for council tax with the second homes premium (200% of standard charge) from April 2025.

You should contact the VOA to have your property reassessed and removed from the business rates list.

Scenario 3: Personal use and family stays

Question: I let my property for 80 days but also use it myself for 30 days. Does it qualify?

Answer: Yes. The 70 days must be commercial lets at market rates. Your personal use doesn't count towards the 70 days, but it doesn't disqualify you either. As long as you had 70 days of paying guests, you meet the criteria.

However: Letting to family and friends at low rates does NOT count towards the 70 days. It must be commercial letting at market rates.

Scenario 4: Seasonal holiday let

Question: My cottage is only available in summer (June to September). Can it still qualify?

Answer: Possibly, but it's challenging. You need to show:

  • The property was available for at least 140 days during that season
  • It was actually let for at least 70 days
  • There's a genuine reason it can't be let year-round (for example, access issues in winter)

If you simply choose not to let it outside summer, it may not meet the "commercial basis" test and could be liable for council tax.

The council's role

Gloucester City Council does not decide whether your property pays council tax or business rates. This is the VOA's decision.

What we do:

  • Issue council tax bills for properties the VOA says should pay council tax
  • Issue business rates bills for properties the VOA says should pay business rates
  • Administer small business rate relief for eligible properties
  • Collect payment of council tax or business rates

What we cannot do:

  • Decide whether your property qualifies for business rates
  • Override VOA decisions
  • Exempt you from the second homes premium if the VOA says you should pay council tax

If you disagree with your classification, you must contact the VOA, not the council. We will follow the VOA's decision.

Contact the Valuation Office Agency

For all questions about whether your property should pay council tax or business rates:

  • To apply for business rates: Contact the VOA with evidence you meet the criteria
  • To challenge a decision: Contact the VOA with new evidence
  • To check your rateable value: Use the VOA website

Visit the VOA website

The VOA can take several weeks to assess your property. Make sure you keep detailed records of your letting activity.

Quick summary

To pay business rates:

  • Available 140+ days
  • Let for 70+ days
  • Commercial basis
  • Genuine intention

Otherwise: Council tax + 100% premium (200% total)
